bibl.title: Letter from Louise Young Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, March 27, 1900

div1.p: Louise Kean writes about family news and political intrigue in Marianao. She comments on Cuban politics.

div1.head: Letter from Louise Young Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, March 27, 1900
div1.p:
It seems perfect
ages since you and the
girls left. Martha and I
have been trying to settle
down to our ways of
long ago, but it is very
hard, the amusing
aunts having been with
us so long.

I found out Saturday the
Sedgewick had finally
gone to Gibara, so I sup-
pose you cannot get to
New York before Thursday.
I hope you were not
frightened by all the
fighting you saw before
you left the harbor.
I saw Mr. Eaton Sunday,
but, of course he had
only noticed how Eve
was affected. Caz I have
not seen. I hope the
shock of finding that
you went to Gibara,
and so delayed the
first letter, was not
too much for him.
Did you suffer from the
heat on your way a-
long the coast? The
south wind has kept
us all very uncomfortable, until this
morning, when the rain came, and
now it is very cool and damp, but a
great relief from the closeness of the
last four days.

I have just finished Martha's three
khaki uniforms, and they are very
becoming. I send you the pattern in
another envelope, likewise the night-
gown one. You remember you were
to buy a piece of rainsook to make
them of, and the embroidery for trimming
as well. Won't you please buy me
an Easter egg for Martha, tho' I
can't send any money until next
week. I think she would love a
rabbit, for Helen's story of the two
little bunnies named Dot and Tot
too made a great impression on her,
and she talks of them all the time.
I think you had better get something
small enough to come by mail.
And, if you can, will
you send Rannie's
headquarter star in
time for Easter? I don't
want to hurry you
Mumsie, but, when you
were here, Easter seemed
so far away, and now
that I have had to
go back to letter writ-
ing again, it seems to
be drawing near very
rapidly.

Last night Rannie and
I walked over to the
hospital to see Dr.
Reed, who was spend-
ing the night there.
He was as lovely as
ever, and unfortunately
expects to leave on Sat-
urday, on the last Tam-
pa boat, so I am afraid
we wont be able to
have even a short vis-
it from him. We sent
you the Havana Herald
with something about
Electrozone and something
about Dady in it.

Poor Mrs. Lee has been
just the same since
you left. First she has
asthma, then bronchitis and then both
at once. She being so wretched and
Ellen looking so dreadfully, I am
afraid may make them leave earlier
than they had planned and, of course,
that will affect me. No orders yet
tho', so we know no more than
we did when you were here.

Sunday there was a big political
meeting in Marianao, what we would
call a primary I think, its sentiments
were in opposition to the present al-
calde, so he had the chairman ar-
rested, and when another was elected and
the tone of the meeting was not
changed he had six or eight of the
leading citizens who were present,
arrested and put in the jail. Their
friends rushed off to General Lee,
who told them his only duty was
to keep the peace and they would
have to run their own politics. I
believe tho' he had a judge dragged
3
out, for these men to
appear before, and I
think they were re-
leased that night. We
have heard, and I am
sure it is true, that
the civil governor of
the province has sent
the alcalde a list of
people he is to keep
his eye on, as they be-
long to the other party,
and the alcalde thought
he was doing a fine
job when he clapped
them in prison so
early in the game, tho'
they are really the -
best men in town.
What queer ideas Cub-
anos have, haven't they?

Miss Egan is still
with us, but will leave
Friday for Key West.

It is high time for
me to dress for dinner
and get Martha to
bed, so I must say
goodnight. I forgot
to tell you that on
Sunday Rannie really
and finally cut the
two wevs out of my
head. They were very tiny, so not
much trouble, and I have not be
conscious of the cuts at all except
when I fix my hair, which I have
to do in a very deft way.

Rannie dined with Mr. Eaton Sun-
day night! but nothing happened.

Love to all the family, I am
anxious to hear how you found
them and how you are. Martha
says to give her love to Gran and
to say she is going to see her
very soon.
div1.closer:
Most lovingly Louise. Poor Col. Wood fell on the marble
steps the other night and broke
his right arm at the wrist.
